Kennedy Jr. |Born| Robert Francis Kennedy Jr. January 17, 1954 |Education| - Environmental lawyer - writer - anti-vaccine activist [Crimes Against Nature](/wiki/Crimes_Against_Nature_(book))(2004 book) [The Riverkeepers](/wiki/The_Riverkeepers)(1997 .com Robert Francis Kennedy Jr. (born January 17, 1954), also known by his initials RFK Jr., is an American environmental lawyer, politician, and writer. He is known for advocating [anti-vaccine](/wiki/Anti-vaccine) misinformation nomination in the [2024 presidential election](/wiki/2024_United_States_presidential_election). Since 2005, he has promoted the scientifically discredited claim of a link between [vaccines and autism](/wiki/Vaccines_and_autism), [[1]](#cite_note-mnookin-2017-1) and is founder and chairman of [Children's Health Defense](/wiki/Children%27s_Health_Defense), an anti-vaccine advocacy group. [[6]](#cite_note-Smith_12/15/2021-6) [[7]](#cite_note-KW-7) Since the onset of [the COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States), Kennedy has emerged as a leading proponent of [COVID-19 vaccine misinformation](/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine_misinformation_and_hesitancy) in the United States. [[8]](#cite_note-8) [[6]](#cite_note-Smith_12/15/2021-6) Much of Kennedy's public health criticisms and writings have targeted prominent figures such as [Anthony Fauci](/wiki/Anthony_Fauci), [Bill Gates](/wiki/Bill_Gates), and [Joe Biden](/wiki/Joe_Biden). He [The Real Anthony Fauci](/wiki/The_Real_Anthony_Fauci) in 2021 and [A Letter to Liberals](/wiki/A_Letter_to_Liberals) in 2022. Kennedy is a son of U.S. attorney general and senator [Robert F. Kennedy](/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy) and nephew of U.S. president [John F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy). After growing up in the [Washington, D.C. area](/wiki/Washington,_D.C._area) and [Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts), he graduated from [Harvard University](/wiki/Harvard_University) and obtained his [Juris Doctor](/wiki/Juris_Doctor) degree from the [University of Virginia School of Law](/wiki/University_of_Virginia_School_of_Law). Kennedy began his career as an assistant district attorney in New York City. In 1984, he joined [Riverkeeper](/wiki/Riverkeeper) and the [Natural Resources Defense Council](/wiki/Natural_Resources_Defense_Council) (NRDC) in 1986, two non-profits focused on environmental protection. [[9]](#cite_note-9) He became an adjunct professor of [environmental law](/wiki/Environmental_law) at [Pace University School of Law](/wiki/Pace_University_School_of_Law) in 1986. [[10]](#cite_note-10) In 1987, he founded the Pace Law School's Environmental Litigation Clinic, where he held the post of supervising attorney and co-director until 2017. [[11]](#cite_note-11) He founded the non-profit environmental group [Waterkeeper Alliance](/wiki/Waterkeeper_Alliance) in 1999, serving as the president of its board. Early life and education Kennedy was born at [Georgetown University Hospital](/wiki/Georgetown_University_Hospital) in Washington, D.C., on January 17, 1954. He is the third of eleven children of senator and attorney general [Robert F. Kennedy](/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy) and [Ethel Kennedy](/wiki/Ethel_Kennedy), [née](/wiki/Birth_name#Maiden_and_married_names) Skakel. He is F. Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy) and Senator [Ted Kennedy](/wiki/Ted_Kennedy). [[12]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOppenheimer20155-6-12) Kennedy grew at and [Cape Cod, Massachusetts](/wiki/Cape_Cod,_Massachusetts). [[13]](#cite_note-13) [[14]](#cite_note-14) [[15]](#cite_note-15) He was nine years old when his uncle, President John F. Kennedy, [was assassinated](/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy) in 1963, and 14 years old when his father [was assassinated](/wiki/Assassination_of_Robert_F._Kennedy) while running for the Democratic presidential nomination in 1968. [[16]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOppenheimer201527-16) Kennedy learned of his father's shooting when he was at [Georgetown Preparatory School](/wiki/Georgetown_Preparatory_School), a [Jesuit](/wiki/Society_of_Jesus) boarding school in North Bethesda, Maryland. [[17]](#cite_note-17) A few hours later, he flew to Los Angeles on vice-president [Hubert Humphrey](/wiki/Hubert_Humphrey)'s plane, along with his elder sister [Kathleen](/wiki/Kathleen_Kennedy_Townsend) and elder brother [Joseph](/wiki/Joseph_P._Kennedy_II), and was with his father when he died. Kennedy was a pallbearer in his father's funeral, where he spoke and read excerpts from his father's speeches at the Mass commemorating his death at [Arlington National Cemetery](/wiki/Arlington_National_Cemetery). [[18]](#cite_note-18) [[19]](#cite_note-19) After his father's death, Kennedy lived with a surrogate family in [Cambridge, Massachusetts](/wiki/Cambridge,_Massachusetts), [[20]](#cite_note-20) and graduated from the Palfrey Street School, a day school in [Watertown, Massachusetts](/wiki/Watertown,_Massachusetts). [[21]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOppenheimer2015144-21) Before attending Palfrey, Kennedy was kicked out of two boarding schools: [Millbrook](/wiki/Millbrook_School) in [upstate New York](/wiki/Upstate_New_York) and [Pomfret](/wiki/Pomfret_School) in [Connecticut](/wiki/Pomfret,_Connecticut) for using drugs. [[22]](#cite_note-22) In August 1970, Kennedy and his cousin [Bobby Shriver](/wiki/Bobby_Shriver) were arrested in [Barnstable, Massachusetts](/wiki/Barnstable,_Massachusetts), for marijuana possession and were placed on 13 months' probation. [[23]](#cite_note-23) [[24]](#cite_note-24) Kennedy continued his education at [Harvard University](/wiki/Harvard_University), graduating in 1976 with a Bachelor of Arts in American history and literature. He later studied at the [London School of Economics](/wiki/London_School_of_Economics) before earning a [Juris Doctor](/wiki/Juris_Doctor) degree from the [University of Virginia School of and a [Master of Laws](/wiki/Master_of_Laws) from [Pace University](/wiki/Pace_University_School_of_Law). [[25]](#cite_note-25) Career In 1982, Kennedy was sworn in as an assistant district attorney for Manhattan. [[7]](#cite_note-KW-7) After failing his bar exam, he resigned in July 1983. [[26]](#cite_note-UPI1989-26) That September, he was charged with heroin possession, [[26]](#cite_note-UPI1989-26) and pleaded guilty in February 1984, whereupon he was sentenced to two years' probation and community service. [[27]](#cite_note-heroin-27) [[28]](#cite_note-living-dangerously-28) Following his arrest he entered a drug treatment center and during his probation volunteered for the [Natural Resources Defense Council](/wiki/Natural_Resources_Defense_Council). His probation ended a year early. [[29]](#cite_note-QuietVictory-29) In 1984, Kennedy joined Riverkeeper as an investigator, and was promoted to senior attorney [[30]](#cite_note-auto4-30) when he was admitted to the New York bar in 1985. [[29]](#cite_note-QuietVictory-29) Kennedy is an environmental law specialist and partner in the law firms of [Morgan & Morgan](/wiki/Morgan_%26_Morgan) and of Kennedy & Madonna, LLP. [[31]](#cite_note-31) Through litigation, lobbying, teaching, and public campaigns and activism, Kennedy has advocated for the protection of waterways, [indigenous rights](/wiki/Indigenous_rights), and [renewable energy](/wiki/Renewable_energy). [[32]](#cite_note-32) In 2018, the National Trial Lawyers Top 100 recognized two law firms for winning a $289 million jury verdict in [Johnson v. Monsanto Co.](/wiki/Johnson_v._Monsanto_Co.). As co-counsel at one of the firms, Kennedy was also a member of the team. [[33]](#cite_note-Millican,_Scott-33) Riverkeeper Kennedy litigated and supervised environmental enforcement lawsuits on the east coast estuaries on behalf of Hudson Riverkeeper and the [Long Island Soundkeeper](/wiki/Soundkeeper), [[34]](#cite_note-34) where he was also a board member. Long Island Soundkeeper brought lawsuits against cities and industries along the Connecticut and New York coastlines. [[35]](#cite_note-35) In 1986, Kennedy was on a team of three law firms that won a case against Remington Arms Trap and Skeet Gun Club in [Stratford, Connecticut](/wiki/Stratford,_Connecticut), that ended the practice of shooting lead shot into [Long Island Sound](/wiki/Long_Island_Sound). [[36]](#cite_note-36) On the Hudson, Kennedy brought a series of lawsuits against municipalities and against industries, including [Consolidated Edison](/wiki/Consolidated_Edison) and [General Electric](/wiki/General_Electric) to stop discharging pollution and to clean up legacy contamination. [[37]](#cite_note-37) In 1995, Kennedy advocated for repeal of legislation during the 104th Congress which he considered unfriendly to the environment. [[38]](#cite_note-auto-38) In 1997, Kennedy worked with John Cronin to write [The Riverkeepers](/wiki/The_Riverkeepers), a history of the early Riverkeepers and a primer for the Waterkeeper movement. [[30]](#cite_note-auto4-30) Kennedy has written about environmental law enforcement. [[39]](#cite_note-watershed-39) Pace Environmental Litigation Clinic In 1987, Kennedy founded the Environmental Litigation Clinic at Pace University School of Law, where for three decades he was the clinic's supervising attorney and co-director and Clinical Professor of Law. [[40]](#cite_note-40) Kennedy obtained a special order from the New York State Court of Appeals that permitted his 10 clinic students-second- and third-year law students-to practice law and to try cases against Hudson River polluters in state and federal court, under the supervision of Kennedy and his co-director, Professor Karl Coplan. The clinic's full-time clients are Riverkeeper and Long Island Soundkeeper. [[41]](#cite_note-oregon-41) The clinic has sued governments and companies for polluting Long Island Sound and the Hudson River and its tributaries. [[42]](#cite_note-42) The clinic argued cases to expand citizen access to the shoreline and won hundreds of settlements for the Hudson Riverkeeper. [[43]](#cite_note-43) Kennedy and his students also sued dozens of municipal waste-water treatment plants to force compliance with the [Clean Water Act](/wiki/Clean_Water_Act). [[41]](#cite_note-oregon-41) In 2010, a Pace lawsuit forced [ExxonMobil](/wiki/ExxonMobil) to clean up tens of millions of gallons of oil from legacy refinery spills in Newtown Creek in Brooklyn, New York. [[44]](#cite_note-44) On April 11, 2001, [Men's Journal](/wiki/Men%27s_Journal) recognized Kennedy with its "Heroes" Award for his creation of the Pace Environmental Litigation Clinic. [[45]](#cite_note-45) Kennedy and his Pace Environmental Litigation Clinic received other awards for successful legal work cleaning up the environment. [[46]](#cite_note-46) The Pace Clinic became a model for similar environmental law clinics throughout the country including Rutgers, [[47]](#cite_note-47) Golden Gate, UCLA, [[48]](#cite_note-48) Widener, [[49]](#cite_note-49) and Boalt Hall at Berkeley. [[50]](#cite_note-50) Waterkeeper Alliance In June 1999, as Riverkeeper's success on the Hudson began inspiring the creation of Waterkeepers across North America, Kennedy and a few dozen Riverkeepers gathered in Southampton, Long Island, to found the Waterkeeper Alliance, which is now the umbrella group for the 344 licensed Waterkeeper programs [[51]](#cite_note-51) located in 44 countries. [[52]](#cite_note-52) As President of the Alliance, Kennedy oversees its legal, membership, policy and fundraising programs. The Alliance states that it is dedicated to promoting "swimmable, fishable, drinkable waterways, worldwide", [[53]](#cite_note-53) and is also a clearinghouse, approving new Keeper programs and licensing use of Kennedy and his environmental work have been the focus of several films including The Waterkeepers (2000), [[55]](#cite_note-55) directed by [Les Guthman](/wiki/Les_Guthman). In 2008, he appeared in the [IMAX](/wiki/IMAX) documentary film [Grand Canyon Adventure: River at Risk](/wiki/Grand_Canyon_Adventure:_River_at_Risk), riding the [Grand Canyon](/wiki/Grand_Canyon) in a wooden dory with his daughter Kick and anthropologist [Wade Davis](/wiki/Wade_Davis_(anthropologist)). [[56]](#cite_note-56) Kennedy resigned from Waterkeeper Alliance presidency in November 2020. [[57]](#cite_note-57) New York City Watershed Agreement Beginning in 1991, Kennedy represented environmentalists and New York City watershed consumers in a series of lawsuits against New York City and upstate watershed polluters. Kennedy authored a series of articles and reports [[58]](#cite_note-58) [[59]](#cite_note-59) [[60]](#cite_note-60) alleging that New York State was abdicating its responsibility to protect the water repository and supply. In 1996, he helped orchestrate the $1.2 billion New York City Watershed Agreement, which [New York](/wiki/New_York_(magazine)) magazine recognized in its cover story, "The Kennedy Who Matters". [[61]](#cite_note-61) This agreement, which Kennedy negotiated on behalf of environmentalists and New York City watershed consumers, is regarded as an international model in stakeholder consensus negotiations and sustainable development. [[62]](#cite_note-62) Kennedy & Madonna LLP In 2000, Kennedy and environmental lawyer Kevin Madonna founded the [environmental law](/wiki/Environmental_law) firm Kennedy & Madonna, LLP, to represent private [plaintiffs](/wiki/Plaintiffs) against polluters. [[63]](#cite_note-63) The firm litigates environmental contamination cases on behalf of individuals, non-profit organizations, school districts, public water suppliers, Indian tribes, municipalities and states. In 2001, Kennedy & Madonna organized a team of prestigious plaintiff law firms to challenge pollution from industrial pork and poultry production. [[64]](#cite_note-64) In 2004, the firm was part of a legal team that secured a $70 million settlement for property owners in Pensacola, Florida whose properties were contaminated by chemicals from an adjacent [Superfund](/wiki/Superfund) site. [[65]](#cite_note-65) Kennedy & Madonna is profiled in the 2010 HBO documentary Mann v. Ford [[66]](#cite_note-66) that chronicles four years of litigation brought by the firm on behalf of the [Ramapough Mountain Indian Tribe](/wiki/Ramapough_Mountain_Indians) against the [Ford Motor Company](/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company) over the dumping of toxic waste on tribal lands in northern New Jersey. [[67]](#cite_note-67) In addition to a monetary settlement for the tribe, the lawsuit contributed to the community's land being re-listed on the federal Superfund list, the first time in the nation's history that a de-listed site was re-listed. [[68]](#cite_note-68) In 2007 Kennedy was one of three finalists nominated as "Trial Lawyer of the Year" by Public Justice for his role in the $396 million jury verdict against [DuPont](/wiki/DuPont) for contamination from its [Spelter, West Virginia](/wiki/Spelter,_West_Virginia) zinc plant. [[69]](#cite_note-69) In 2017, the firm was part of the trial team that secured a $670 million settlement on behalf of over 3,000 residents from Ohio and West Virginia whose drinking water was contaminated with the toxic chemical, C8, which was released into the environment by [DuPont](/wiki/DuPont) in [Parkersburg](/wiki/Parkersburg), West Virginia. [[70]](#cite_note-70) Morgan & Morgan In 2016, Kennedy became counsel to the [Morgan & Morgan](/wiki/Morgan_%26_Morgan) law firm. [[71]](#cite_note-71) The partnership arose from the two firms' successful collaboration on the case against SoCalGas Company following the [Aliso Canyon gas leak](/wiki/Aliso_Canyon_gas_leak) in California. [[72]](#cite_note-72) In 2017, Kennedy and his partners sued Monsanto in federal court in San Francisco, on behalf of plaintiffs seeking to recover damages for [non-Hodgkin's lymphoma](/wiki/Non-Hodgkin%27s_lymphoma), that, the plaintiffs allege, were a result of exposure to Monsanto's [glyphosate](/wiki/Glyphosate)-based herbicide, [Roundup](/wiki/Roundup_(herbicide)). Kennedy and his team also filed a class action lawsuit against [Monsanto](/wiki/Monsanto) for failing to warn consumers about the dangers allegedly posed by exposure to Roundup. [[73]](#cite_note-73) In September 2018, Kennedy and his partners filed a class-action lawsuit against [Columbia Gas of Massachusetts](/wiki/Columbia_Gas_of_Massachusetts) alleging negligence following [gas explosions](/wiki/Merrimack_Valley_gas_explosions) in three towns north of Boston. Of Columbia Gas, Kennedy said "as they build new miles of pipe, the same company is ignoring its existing infrastructure, which we now know is eroding and is dilapidated". [[74]](#cite_note-74) Renewable energy In 1998, Kennedy, Chris Bartle and John Hoving created a [bottled-water](/wiki/Bottled_water) company, Keeper Springs, which donated all of its profits to Waterkeeper Alliance. [[75]](#cite_note-75) In 2013, Kennedy and his partner sold the brand to [Nestlé](/wiki/Nestl%C3%A9) in exchange for a donation to local Waterkeepers. [[76]](#cite_note-76) Kennedy was a venture partner and senior advisor at VantagePoint Capital Partners, one of the world's largest [cleantech](/wiki/Clean_technology) [venture capital](/wiki/Venture_capital) firms. Among other activities, VantagePoint was the original and largest pre- [IPO](/wiki/IPO) institutional investor in [Tesla](/wiki/Tesla,_Inc.). VantagePoint also backed BrightSource Energy and Solazyme, amongst others. Kennedy is a board member and counselor to several of Vantage Point's portfolio companies in the water and energy space, including Ostara, a Vancouver-based company that markets the technology to remove [phosphorus](/wiki/Phosphorus) and other excessive nutrients from [wastewater](/wiki/Wastewater), transforming otherwise pollution directly into high-grade fertilizer. [[77]](#cite_note-77) He is also a senior advisor to Starwood Energy Group and has played a key role in a number of the firm's investments. [[78]](#cite_note-78) He is on the board of Vionx, a [Massachusetts](/wiki/Massachusetts)-based utility scale [vanadium flow battery](/wiki/Vanadium_flow_battery) systems manufacturer. October 5, 2017, Vionx, [National Grid](/wiki/National_Grid_plc) and the [U.S. Department of Energy](/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Energy) completed the installation of advanced flow batteries at [Holy Name High School](/wiki/Holy_Name_Central_Catholic_High_School) in the city of [Worcester, Massachusetts](/wiki/Worcester,_Massachusetts). The collaboration also includes [Siemens](/wiki/Siemens) and the [United Technologies](/wiki/United_Technologies) Research Center and constitutes one of the largest energy storage facilities in Massachusetts. [[79]](#cite_note-79) Kennedy is a Partner in ColorZen, which offers a turnkey cotton fiber pre-treatment solution that reduces water usage and toxic discharges in the cotton dyeing process. [[80]](#cite_note-80) Kennedy was a co-owner and Director of the [smart grid](/wiki/Smart_grid) company Utility Integration Solutions (UISol), [[81]](#cite_note-81) which was acquired by [Alstom](/wiki/Alstom). He is presently a co-owner and Director of GridBright, the market-leading grid management specialist. [[82]](#cite_note-82) In October 2011, Kennedy co-founded EcoWatch, an environmental news site. He resigned from its board of directors in January 2018. [[83]](#cite_note-83) Minority and poor communities In his first case as an environmental attorney, Kennedy represented the [NAACP](/wiki/NAACP) in a lawsuit against a proposal to build a garbage transfer station in a minority neighborhood in [Ossining, New York](/wiki/Ossining,_New_York_(village)). [[84]](#cite_note-84) In 1987, he successfully sued [Westchester County](/wiki/Westchester_County,_New_York), New York, to reopen the [Croton Point Park](/wiki/Croton_Point_Park), which was heavily used primarily by poor and minority communities from [the Bronx](/wiki/The_Bronx). [[85]](#cite_note-85) He then forced the reopening of the [Pelham Bay Park](/wiki/Pelham_Bay_Park) in the Bronx, which New York City had closed to the public and converted to a police firing range. [[30]](#cite_note-auto4-30) Kennedy has argued that poor communities shoulder the disproportionate burden of environmental pollution. [[86]](#cite_note-86) Speaking at the 2016 [SXSW](/wiki/South_by_Southwest) Eco environment conference in [Austin, Texas](/wiki/Austin,_Texas), he said, "Polluters always choose the soft target of poverty", noting that Chicago's [south side](/wiki/South_Side,_Chicago) has the highest concentration of toxic waste dumps in America. [[87]](#cite_note-87) Furthermore, he added that 80 percent of "uncontrolled toxic waste dumps" can be found in black neighborhoods, with the largest site in the United States being in [Emelle, Alabama](/wiki/Emelle,_Alabama), which is 90 percent black. [[88]](#cite_note-88) International and indigenous rights Starting in 1985, Kennedy helped develop the [Natural Resources Defense Council](/wiki/Natural_Resources_Defense_Council) (NRDC)'s international program for environmental, energy, and human rights, traveling to Canada and Latin America to assist indigenous tribes in protecting their homelands and opposing large-scale energy and extractive projects in remote wilderness areas. [[89]](#cite_note-89) In 1990, Kennedy assisted indigenous [Pehuenches](/wiki/Pehuenche) in Chile in a partially successful campaign to stop the construction of a series of dams on Chile's iconic [Biobío River](/wiki/Biob%C3%ADo_River). That campaign derailed all but one of the proposed dams. [[90]](#cite_note-90) Beginning in 1992, he assisted the [Cree](/wiki/Cree) Indians of northern Quebec in their campaign against [Hydro-Québec](/wiki/Hydro-Qu%C3%A9bec) to halt construction of some 600 proposed dams on eleven rivers in [James Bay](/wiki/James_Bay). [[91]](#cite_note-91) In 1993, Kennedy and NRDC, working with the indigenous rights organization [Cultural Survival](/wiki/Cultural_Survival), clashed with other American environmental groups in a dispute about the rights of Indians to govern their own lands in the [Oriente](/wiki/Oriente_(Ecuador)) region of Ecuador. [[92]](#cite_note-auto6-92) Kennedy represented the [CONFENIAE](/wiki/CONFENIAE), a confederation of Indian peoples, in negotiation with the American oil company [Conoco](/wiki/Conoco) to limit oil development in Ecuadorian Amazon and, at the same time, obtain benefits from resource extraction for Amazonian tribes. [[92]](#cite_note-auto6-92) Kennedy was a vocal critic of [Texaco](/wiki/Texaco) for its previous record for polluting the Ecuadoran Amazon. [[93]](#cite_note-93) From 1993 to 1999, Kennedy worked with five [Vancouver Island](/wiki/Vancouver_Island) Indian tribes in their campaign to end industrial logging by [MacMillan Bloedel](/wiki/MacMillan_Bloedel) in [Clayoquot Sound](/wiki/Clayoquot_Sound), British Columbia. [[94]](#cite_note-94) In 1996, Kennedy met with Cuban President [Fidel Castro](/wiki/Fidel_Castro) to persuade the leader to halt his plans to construct a nuclear power plant at [Juraguá](/wiki/Juragu%C3%A1). [[95]](#cite_note-95) During a lengthy latenight encounter, Castro reminisced about Kennedy's father and uncle, speculating that U.S. relations with Cuba would have been far better had President Kennedy not been assassinated. [[96]](#cite_note-96) Between 1996 and 2000, Kennedy and NRDC helped Mexican commercial fishermen to halt [Mitsubishi](/wiki/Mitsubishi)'s proposal to build a salt facility in the [Laguna San Ignacio](/wiki/Laguna_San_Ignacio), a known area in Baja where [gray whales](/wiki/Gray_whale) bred, and nursed their calves. [[97]](#cite_note-97) Kennedy wrote against the project, and took the campaign to Japan, meeting with the Japanese Prime Minister [Keizo Obuchi](/wiki/Keizo_Obuchi). [[98]](#cite_note-98) In 2000, he assisted local environmental activists to stop proposals by Chaffin Light, a real estate developer, and U.S. engineering giant [Bechtel](/wiki/Bechtel) from building a large hotel and resort development that, Kennedy argued, threatened [coral reefs](/wiki/Coral_reef) and public beaches used by local Bahamians, at Clifton Bay, [New Providence](/wiki/New_Providence) Island. [[99]](#cite_note-99) Kennedy was one of the early editors of [Indian Country Today](/wiki/Indian_Country_Today), North America's largest [Native American](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas) newspaper. [[100]](#cite_note-100) He helped lead the opposition to the damming of the [Futaleufú River](/wiki/Futaleuf%C3%BA_River) in the [Patagonia](/wiki/Patagonia) region of Chile. [[101]](#cite_note-101) In 2016, citing the pressure precipitated by the Futaleufú Riverkeeper's campaign against the dams, the Spanish power company, [Endesa](/wiki/Endesa), which owned the right to dam the river, reversed its decision and relinquished all claims to the Futaleufú. [[102]](#cite_note-102) Military and Vieques Kennedy has been a critic of environmental damage by the U.S. military. [[103]](#cite_note-103) [[104]](#cite_note-104) In a 2001 article, Kennedy described how he sued the [U.S. Navy](/wiki/U.S._Navy) on behalf of fishermen and residents of [Vieques](/wiki/Vieques), an island off [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico), to stop weapons testing, bombing, and other military exercises. Kennedy argued that the activities were unnecessary, and that the Navy had illegally destroyed several endangered species, polluted the island's waters, harmed the residents' health, and damaged its economy. [[105]](#cite_note-vieques-105) He was arrested for trespassing at [Camp Garcia Vieques](/wiki/Camp_Garcia_Vieques), the [U.S. Navy](/wiki/U.S._Navy) training facility, where he and others were protesting the use of a section of the island for training. Kennedy served 30 days in a maximum security prison in Puerto Rico. [[106]](#cite_note-106) The trespassing incident forced the suspension of [live-fire exercises](/wiki/Live-fire_exercise) for almost three hours. [[107]](#cite_note-107) The lawsuits and protests by Kennedy, and hundreds of Puerto Ricans who were also imprisoned, eventually forced the termination of naval bombing in Vieques by president George Bush. [[108]](#cite_note-108) In a 2003 article for the [Chicago Tribune](/wiki/Chicago_Tribune), Kennedy said the U.S. federal government was "America's biggest polluter" and the [U.S. Department of Defense](/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Defense) as the worst offender. Citing the [EPA](/wiki/Environmental_Protection_Agency), he said, "unexploded ordnance waste can be found on 16,000 military ranges...and more than half may contain biological or chemical weapons". [[109]](#cite_note-109) Factory farms For almost twenty years, Kennedy and his Waterkeepers waged a legal and public relations battle against pollution by factory farms. In the 1990s, he rallied opposition to factory farms among small independent farmers, convened a series of "National Summits" on factory meat products, and conducted press conference whistle stop tours across North Carolina, Iowa, Kansas, Missouri, Illinois, Ohio and in Washington DC. Beginning in 2000, Kennedy sued factory farms in North Carolina, Oklahoma, Maryland, and Iowa. [[110]](#cite_note-porkchop-110) He wrote numerous articles on the subject, arguing that factory farms produce lower-quality, less healthy food, and are harmful to independent family farmers by poisoning their air and water, reducing their property values, and using extensive state and federal subsidies to impose unfair competition against smaller farmers. [[111]](#cite_note-111) In 1995, Premier [Ralph Klein](/wiki/Ralph_Klein) of Alberta declared Kennedy persona non grata in the province due to Kennedy's activism against Alberta's large-scale hog production facilities. [[112]](#cite_note-112) In 2002, [Smithfield Foods](/wiki/Smithfield_Foods) filed a lawsuit against Kennedy in Poland, under a Polish law that makes criticizing a corporation illegal, after Kennedy denounced the company in a debate with Smithfield's Polish director before the Polish parliament. [[110]](#cite_note-porkchop-110) Oil, gas, and pipelines Kennedy has been an advocate for a global transition away from fossil fuels toward renewable energy. [[113]](#cite_note-113) [[114]](#cite_note-114) He has been particularly critical of the oil industry. In one of his first environmental cases, Kennedy filed a lawsuit against [Mobil Oil](/wiki/Mobil_Oil) for polluting the Hudson. [[30]](#cite_note-auto4-30) Kennedy helped lead the battle against fracking in New York State. [[115]](#cite_note-115) He had been an early supporter of natural gas as viable bridge fuel to renewables, and a cleaner alternative to coal. [[116]](#cite_note-116) However, he said he turned against this controversial extraction method after investigating its cost to public health, climate and road infrastructure. [[117]](#cite_note-117) As a member of Governor [Andrew Cuomo](/wiki/Andrew_Cuomo)'s fracking commission, Kennedy helped engineer the Governor's 2013 ban on fracking in New York State. [[118]](#cite_note-118) Kennedy mounted a national effort against the construction of liquefied natural gas facilities. [[119]](#cite_note-119) Waterkeepers maintains a national watch that documents numerous crude oil spills annually. In 2013, Kennedy assisted the [Chipewyan](/wiki/Chipewyan) First Nation and the [Beaver Lake Cree](/wiki/Beaver_Lake_Cree_Nation) fighting to protect their land from [tar sands](/wiki/Oil_sands) production. [[120]](#cite_note-macleans-120) In February 2013, while protesting the [Keystone XL Pipeline](/wiki/Keystone_XL_Pipeline) Kennedy, along with his son, Conor, was arrested for blocking a thoroughfare in front of the White House during a protest. [[121]](#cite_note-121) In August 2016, Kennedy and Waterkeeper participated in protests to block the extension of the [Dakota Access pipeline](/wiki/Dakota_Access_pipeline) across the [Sioux](/wiki/Sioux) Indian [Standing Rock Reservation](/wiki/Standing_Rock_Reservation)'s water supply.
